  physical_appearance: This is an aerial view of a dock. The meandering river is filled with ships of various sizes
 and the land across seems vast and expansive with sparse settlement. This artwork depicts a landscape view of the East India Docks. The top half of the aquatint consists of the sky and clouds
 while the bottom half depicts the ships
 docks
 and rivers. The artwork has a wooden frame and it has a white border with a brown perimeter in between. At the bottom of the artwork
 its title is displayed in capital letters. Under its title
 there are four rows of paragraphs describing aspects of the East India docks. The colours on the aquatint do not look smudged.

  subject_terms_1: docks (waterfront spaces) ships marines (visual works) landscapes (representations) dockyards shipping

  sgcool_label_text: The East India Docks were opened in 1806 in Blackwall
 London
 to accommodate the shipping needs of the East India Company. This aquatint presents an aerial view of the docks
 with the Thames in the middle ground
 and Greenwich in the distance to the right. It was drawn
 engraved and published by William Daniell
 an English landscape and marine artist who together with his uncle Thomas Daniell  travelled extensively in India.

metadata.object_work_type: aquatints (prints) paperwork (visual works) aerial views aquatints engravings (prints)
metadata.title_text: A View of the East India Docks
metadata.physical_appearance: This is an aerial view of a dock. The meandering river is filled with ships of various sizes, and the land across seems vast and expansive with sparse settlement. This artwork depicts a landscape view of the East India Docks. The top half of the aquatint consists of the sky and clouds, while the bottom half depicts the ships, docks, and rivers. The artwork has a wooden frame and it has a white border with a brown perimeter in between. At the bottom of the artwork, its title is displayed in capital letters. Under its title, there are four rows of paragraphs describing aspects of the East India docks. The colours on the aquatint do not look smudged.
metadata.subject_terms_1: docks (waterfront spaces) ships marines (visual works) landscapes (representations) dockyards shipping

metadata.subject_terms_3: East India Company Visual Arts Visual arts
metadata.sgcool_label_text: The East India Docks were opened in 1806 in Blackwall, London, to accommodate the shipping needs of the East India Company. This aquatint presents an aerial view of the docks, with the Thames in the middle ground, and Greenwich in the distance to the right. It was drawn, engraved and published by William Daniell, an English landscape and marine artist who together with his uncle Thomas Daniell  travelled extensively in India.
